sense.name: spread of printed material
sense.commentary: CIRCULATION[+event] The dissemination of copies of periodicals, usually newspapers and magazines.
sense.examples: The article is currently in circulation in the latest issue of "Nature". The circulation period of a typical newspaper is about two days.

sense.name: physical movement
sense.commentary: CIRCULATION[+event] The physical movement of something, usually around a circuit. Refers most commonly to the movement of blood.
sense.examples: I opened a window to get some air circulation in here. John had poor circulation in his legs. The circulation of water was impeded by a pipe blockage.

sense.name: number of printed materials
sense.commentary: The number of copies of a periodical that are sold.
sense.examples: By increasing its circulation, the newspaper hoped to increase advertising revenue.

sense.name: library books
sense.commentary: The number of books that are loaned by a library over a specific period.
sense.examples: John stopped at the circulation desk to see if "Stranger in a Strange Land" was currently in stock.

sense.name: non-physical motion
sense.commentary: CIRCULATION[+event] The spread or transmission of something to a group or area. Refers often to ideas and money.
sense.examples: The dictator tried to stop the circulation of democratic ideals. In Italy, both lira and euros are currently in circulation.
